reviewText: I watched this twice before giving it a rating, mainly after reading a fairly negative review in the Maltin Movie Guide. Thought it deserved a lot more than **1/2  but obviously this film isn't going to appeal to all tastes. In my opinion though, this film is an absorbing study of a difficult ten year relationship between two very flawed characters.  The acting was exemplary, especially by Thure Lindhardt as Erik;  this surely is his breakthrough role as an actor.  I found him and his performance absolutely fascinating to watch; even his audition tape (one of the many fine extras on the DVD) was fun to watch.  Found the sexual tensions between Erik and Paul and their various peccadillos were handled with honesty and realism by director Ira Sachs.  Perhaps a bit slow at times but overall this excellent Bergman-style film deserves a wide and appreciative audience.
summary: EXCELLENT STUDY OF A DIFFICULT RELATIONSHIP

reviewText: It's NYC in the late 1990's, where Erik (Thure Lindhardt) is a budding filmmaker from Denmark, supported by his family while working on a documentary for the past four years. While trolling for sex on a phone line, he meets Paul (Zachary Booth), and closeted attorney for a publisher, they discover a sexual and emotional connection, and eventually move in together. Erik is aware, early on, that Paul smokes crack cocaine, but is unaware of how his addiction is growing, to the point where he eventually disappears from his job and their apartment. They manage to stay together for close to a decade, despite Paul's stints in rehab and subsequent failures to maintain his sobriety. Erik sees Paul's failures as a reflection of his own inability to follow-through on things (like his film), and becomes obsessed with "saving" Paul, despite friends' advice and common sense telling him it just may not happen, despite his best efforts and intentions.Based loosely on a personal experience by the movie's director/co-writer, Ira Sacks, the film's subject matter is obviously rather dark and depressing at times, though realistic for someone going through a rather masochistic relationship with an addict. The acting and technical quality are first rate, although the film's pacing seems to bog down at times, suggesting that more editing would have been an improvement. Film is unrated (would be an R for sexual content, though no complete nudity), and appeared in several film festivals (including Sundance). DVD extras include "Making of" short, deleted scenes, commentary and auditions. Although this film has gotten a lot of attention, I didn't find it that impressive, and am being generous with three stars out of five.
summary: Dark story of one flawed individual trying to "save" another.

reviewText: There's little redemption in this film that follows the failed relationship between two 30-something men over roughly a 10 year period.  As I watched the movie, I kept hoping it wouldn't did any deeper into a well of isolation, abuse and co-dependency, but it just kept going deeper.  While many can relate to some level of difficulty in a relationship, this throws so many issues into the mix, you can't help but ask why either one of the characters stay?  It is an essay in co-dependent relationships, and that is the only redeeming value in the film.  I couldn't connect with either of the two main characters, which didn't help the plight of the film.  On one hand, you have Erik, an aspiring artist / filmmaker who is somewhat sex addicted and completely dependent upon his lover Paul.  To the extent he watches as Paul has sex with a stranger while high on drugs.  Paul is identified as an attorney, who has a drug addiction and falls off the wagon after going for treatment in Minnesota.While the topics are relevant to some, the acting was not superb, and the film is a dark abyss of chaos and abuse. Trust me, I would be supportive of a partner with a drug issue, but I also would be smart enough never to start a relationship with someone who already has one, as Erik does in this story.  I would not recommend or watch again.
summary: Depressing Saga of Relationship Co-Dependency & Drug Abuse
Title: N/A

reviewText: True love can be difficult to realize in the face of innumerable and unknown life impediments. These impediments, along with self-inflicted wounds from the emotional DNA we all carry (and which often expresses itself in relationship(s) with others), leaves these two people blissful, vulnerable and ignorant.  Drug addiction or an addiction of any kind is anathema to any relationship(s). Often there is the enabler/co-dependent and the addicted one, who doesn't perceive the danger ahead. We get all of this in Keep the Lights On. It is a roller coaster of discovery for both of the individuals in the relationship, fascinating and heartbreaking to watch, but never vapid.  Over a decade, the individuals in this story really do try to find a way to make their relationship work and it was refreshing to see the enormous, even herculean effort the two principals in this love drama expend in order to save each other and their relationship. The acting is superb and the attention to detail in the direction (showing not telling), draws the viewers into the depths of what two individuals may experience on the road to finding themselves and one another.
summary: Superb acting, hopeful and heartbreaking, verismatic.

reviewText: This movie now ranks of one of my favorite movies.  "Keep the Lights on" is a movie between two gay men but it is not your usual gay, cliched movie.  This movie was about the relationship between two men who were in love and about thier trials and tribulations as they try to make thier relationship work.  No matter how much you love someone, you cannot save them. Sometimes it is better to just walk away.  Bravo to both the lead actors and to the director.  I am now a fan of Thure Lindhardt.

reviewText: This is a very well done portrayal of the degradation of a person who has taken to very heavy drugs and it's effects on those around him. It is also a record of loyalty and love of one person to the other until even that is stretched beyond its limits, through the endless programs of detoxification. 'Smack' will never let go of an addict--it seems to go to molecular level and can't be gotten out.The story was well told by the actors, particularly by Thure Lindhardt and Zachary Booth. The final scenes were, as they should be,an ending as it had to be, Erik finally realising that he could do no more. In fact, he had well and truly found that Paul wasn't the person he loved at all. Paul had been a stranger for some time--Erik's friends had tried to tell him--and as we all know, love makes one want to overcome all difficulties, and it takes a very strong person to finally admit he has failed. But at least he had tried for 9 years. At the end I was, hoping that Erik would find find someone else. I wonder if he did? I liked this film for its honesty.

reviewText: I watched this because I'm a fan of Thure Lindhart. He was pretty decent in the film, however I've seen him in much better films. I believe he was limited by the mediocre script, directing and co-actors. This is a run of the mill gay story of a guy trying to save his drug-addict boyfriend. Very basic made for tv movie drivel. Nothing particularly new or interesting happens here.  The story is pretty disjointed and the editing is odd as you never know where you are in the story. They do flash a couple of dates on the screen so you have an idea of what year it is, but it was pointless. Did 8 years actually pass? Much more should've happened. They don't really explore any of the characters in any depth. This probably would've worked better as a short film, or in the hands of a more experienced writer and director.  All in all, Thure was the only good thing about this, and he wasn't all that great.
summary: Just ok. More like an overly long made for tv movie.

reviewText: And yes, there is gay sex and PG nudity, but that's not the "adult" I reference. Usually gay films for me are a big D. D for dull; D for dreary; D for depressing and disillusioned.With "Keep the Lights On" I begin to hold some sliver of hope that gay film making and writing may be finally ready to grow up.  In this movie audiences are treated to the life cycle of a gay relationship between 30-something men in Manhattan. The realistic and non-sensational treatment of sexual incompatibility and drug addiction are nicely done. Although clearly dysfunctional, the two main characters were fixtures in each other's life.So refreshing a respite from the inane 20-something chatter played out in a club setting about who's hot and who can sleep with whom next. I wouldn't mind more gay ADULT (in the best meaning of the word) films of this caliber.
summary: Among the few adult gay movies

reviewText: How many films have now been made on how addiction of any kind poisons an affair between two people deeply in love? In "Keep the Lights On," the theme is given a good reanimation by the blond hero whose slow awakening to the fact that his partner's hopeless commitment to a drug takes precedent over their own relationship. The feelings remain, but the hero knows when it's time to get out and get back together with his own life. Harsh but wise.
summary: Lots of wisdom on a rather exhausted theme

reviewText: Keep The Lights On (2012). Not Rated. Running Time: 1 hour, 41 mins.Directed by Ira Sachs. Written by Ira Sachs and Mauricio Zacharias.Original Music by Arthur Russell.The movie previews before the option menu can not be skipped. They have to play through to get to the option menu.Erik (Thure Lindhardt) is on a gay phone line service trying to talk to and meet someone for the evening. He gets a hook and goes to Chelsea. At the apartment, he meets Paul (Zachary Booth), they kiss immediately and have sex.Afterwards, Paul tells Erik he has a girlfriend and not to get his hopes up.The next morning, Eric has a radio interview where he talks about being a filmmaker.Erik meets another man, Russ (Sebastian LaCause), but he just wants to show off his muscular body. No sex.Of all the men, Erik has met, it is Paul he develops a relationship with. Erik even finds out he does not have HIV. So everything is okay, right?Paul has a secret.Also in the cast: Paprika Steen, Sarah Hess, Justin Markell, Miguel del Toro. Marilyn Neimark, James Bidgood, John Michael Cox, Henry Arango, Agosto Arango, Todd Verow appear as themselves.Contains male nudity and sexual situations.In-film advertising: Banana Republic.Language and Subtitles in English only.Audio Commentary with Director Ira Sochs.Special Features: In Search of Avery Willard. Making of Keep The Lights On. 5 Deleted Scenes. Thure Lindhardt audition. Zachary Booth audition. Teaser Trailer.
summary: You meet, you love, and then you find out.

reviewText: You know what? I'm not interested in people who destroy their lives with drugs. And I'm not interested in people who destroy their lives by attaching themselves like leeches to people who are destroying their lives with drugs. That's not tragic; that's not romantic; that's stupid.In every case—the enabler-leeches just as much as the addicts—that kind of behavior is self-indulgent, narcissistic, and completely avoidable. I don't feel sorry for them any more than I feel sorry for billionaires who whine about having to pay taxes or for 21st-century hunter-gatherers who whine if we try take away their constitutionally-mandated 1000-round-per-second assault rifles.That's what this profoundly disappointing movie is about: whining idiots whose lives are totally devoted to stupid, avoidable, totally unnecessary, self-indulgent, destructive behavior. This movie is not about love. It's not about what it means to be a gay man. It's about stupidity.The problem is that it proclaims to the world that we gay men are self centered, self-indulgent, drug-crazed idiots and the self centered, self-indulgent idiot men who "love" them. Bullsh!t. There is no love ANYWHERE in this lying, infuriating movie. The gay men who gush about how REAL this movie is must be like the ones portrayed in it. Thank God I don't know any of them.For the information of straight readers: gay men like the ones in this movie are a tiny, TINY, insignificant, completely negligible minority who do not in any way represent the community as a whole. The percentage of gay crack addicts is no greater than the percentage of straight crack addicts, and ALL of them are just as boring as the two in this movie are. Most gay men are just like straight men, except a little smarter and with better taste in sex partners.The two stars are for Thure Lindhardt, a beautiful man in every way, who plays gay characters better than any gay actor I can think of. I first saw him in the Danish movie Broderskab (Brotherhood), in which his excellent, subtle performance was overshadowed by Swedish actor David Dencik in the most powerful portrayal of a gay man I've ever seen.Lindhardt doesn't have such intense acting competition in this movie, so he shines more brightly. Although his character is a boring, infuriating fool, his performance is fantastic. Lindhardt is always worth watching, and—for me—he's the only reason this movie is.
summary: Profoundly disappointing, but Thure Lindhardt shines
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is one of the best films I've seen dealing with the social impact of drug use on contemporary gay relationships. But, of course, it's much more than that. It's about love too. The film touches on just about every issue confronting highly privileged, young, relatively affluent gay men living and working in an urban environment. It's well filmed, well acted and the story was realistically told and engaging. Yes, there were some not-so subtle, one dimensional gay and extended gay family stereotypes in the mix, but overall the characters were mostly believable and authentic.The sound track was good too. Overall, I really liked this movie and might even watch it a second time.
summary: A Compelling Film About Addiction and Love in Contemporary Relationships

reviewText: A look at addiction, personalities and the human condition.  Gay relationships are presented in less of a cartoon form where behaviors and motivations have depth and even unexpected surprise.  Brokeback Mountain seems to have opened a door to this form of treatment of gay relationships.  This movie is not equivalent to Brokeback Mountain, but it is surprisingly enjoyable and interesting.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is the story of two men who love each other deeply but can't let go of their addictions. Paul,a corporate lawyer free bases cocaine, Erik a Danish documentary filmmaker turns to other men the end result ultimately is that they just can't trust each other. It is a familiar story in contemporary gay relationships. Things begin in New York of the late nineties when Erik and Paul meet on a phone sex hotline, a common occurrence in the days before the internet and Grindr became ubiquitous. The production values bring this period accurately to life. The two men hook up and seem never to part from that day on. Paul is honest about his cocaine use but swears Erik to secrecy. What at first seems a recreational habit turns out to be an uncontrollable addiction with Paul disappearing for days at a time. Erik seems to be addicted to casual hook ups on the phone lines, while away he and Paul actually encounter each other on one. The relationship endures for a decade with neither of the characters seemingly willing to let go, until reality finally intervenes. This is the honest and sensitive portrayal of a contemporary gay relationship and it is hard not to get caught up in the characters lives. I can actually see one of my own early relationships in this film, and it is not exactly comfortable to watch at times.
Title: N/A

Title: N/A

reviewText: Ah, finally, an American film that has the texture of a European film — I like it! Visually, Keep the Lights On is soft, it is like someone's soft hands are caressing thy face — feels good — I gotta watch it again!Thure Lindhardt's performance is frighteningly natural and deeply moving. Thure and Zachary made a believable couple on screen.The story, at certain points, is a bit predictable, but that's easily overlooked because the overall drama is kept totally real: a practical archetype of homosexual relationships, whether for good or for bad.Ultimately, Keep the Lights On makes one think, rather than answer all existential questions, especially those related to intimate relationships.The ending took me by surprise, because it seems out of place with Thure's character's desires -- I guess we all do things out of character, don't we? Or, are we just addicted to happily-ever-after endings?I enjoyed viewing Keep the Lights On — it was like viewing a re-enactments of a piece of history — something that actually happened. Cosidering that mainstream culture demands overly dramatic and action-packed films, subtlty and realness is highly underestimated.The epidemic of nonsense and unnecessary violence in films is starting to create an audience for back-to-basics type of art. Keep the Lights On focuses on the simple, real and powerful dynamics of relationships — no bells and whistles, just a reality of how fragile, beautiful and tragic relationships can be.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Even in bad gay flicks, at least there is juicy sex. Not here, babe. The "plot" such as it is, is simple: Erik is infatuated, nay obsessed, with Paul. Paul is narcissistic, a bit schizophrenic, and self-destructive (i.e. crack head hustler). In theirnine-year relationship, he goes off for days and weeks on end, driving Erik crazy with worry. But Erik won't take no for an answer... and so on. Because there isn't much of a plot, the writer just drags it out and perseverates: he makes you think a resolution is around the corner, but it never is. Not worth the hour and forty-five minutes of monotony. A surprising bomb from the usually spot-on Yellow Bird production company, which brought us the Dragon Tattoo trilogy. In a word: DESPICABLE.
summary: Turn off the lights and change the channel!

reviewText: Too bad that everything in this movie isn't as good as the acting! While the male lead actors are quite believable, the movie suffers mostly from a lack of character development and a rather uneventful storyline. From watching the film, I couldn't figure out what Paul was all about. The script doesn't ever shed any light on what his demons are that fueled his drug addiction. It's revealed that Paul stresses over the responsibility and workload of his job, but who doesn't? And any stress from him being a closeted gay male is not really explored in any depth, so I really have no clue why he was strung out. There was also no clarity on why Erick didn't want to remain with Paul after he seemingly got himself straightened out--something Erick had long hoped for. As a result, the final scene felt "lifeless" and "emotionless", because I really didn't get a sense of who they actually were as people or even why they were bonded in the first place.
summary: Fine acting in "Keep the Lights On"

reviewText: Over time as you watch more and more LGBT dramas, you inevitably encounter common themes across a lot of these movies. In terms of Keep the Lights On, we have quite a number of them including AIDS, lots of casual sex, infidelity, dysfunctional relationships and others. I could keep on listing but I don't want to spoil latter aspects of the movie just yet.To be fair, the actors in this movie are pretty competent. While I'd never think of Lindhardt as being very masculine, as he was described by another character in the movie, he certainly has a quite intensity about him that presents his part of the story pretty well. It's hard to discuss Booth's acting skills though given a lot of the times he's supposed to be high and engaging in rather questionable behavior.The core story is an appropriately sad and somber one - something that we have come to expect from such independent films, I feel. In the same way that a lot of local indie movies focus on the poverty that is ever-present, this movie covers a lot of ground that feels familiar to me, only because a lot of queer fiction seems to cover it was well. And that's neither here nor there - creatives try to tell the stories that they know and are most familiar to them. Thus we keep coming back to stories like this.Keep the Lights On is not a bad movie, but personally did not feel all that new to me either. And maybe a large factor is the fact that I don't appreciate substance abuse and too much promiscuity as supposedly being practically traditions in pink culture.
summary: Feels Like Almost Any Other LGBT Drama

reviewText: Love is blind, as said I believe by William Shakespeare.  Here are two men who meet for a sexual hook up, and end up a couple on and off for 10 years.  Roger Ebert said it best by saying these two should never have been a couple.  And it is true.  The main character Eric is a documentary film maker hopeless romantic, and Paul, a conservative, 9-5 worker with a crack addiction.  Why are they together?  Eric gets emotionally abused and sexually frustrated, while Paul is selfish and cannot kick his crack habit.  This is one of the most realistic movies to date about two gay men in a relationship.  The acting is superb (especially Thure Lindhardt playing Eric,) the story is pitch perfect, and a movie every gay man needs to watch.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Between bouts of casual sex with strangers and working on his new documentary, Danish film maker Erik (Thure Lindhardt) is fighting to keep his drowning relationship with boyfriend Paul afloat. Paul, played by Zachary Booth, is a lawyer, drug addict, and uncontrollable wreck. Erik naively believes he can help him, but we all know how it will turn out.So we have the set up for Ira Sachs' drama "Keep the lights on." A film that isn't solely about gay relationships, but about just plain bad ones. And boy what a bad one Paul and Erik have. It would be easy to say that protagonists Paul and Erik have a broken romance, but when was it ever fixed? Even from the beginning something isn't quite right about their chemistry. They seem aloof from one another, yet there's a negative electricity holding them together. Erik meets other people who would offer a much nicer relationship, but he remains apprehensive to follow. Lights' is memorable for its  performances from Booth and Lindhardt. They are both fascinating to watch. True, they don't have much chemistry, but I think that's What makes their relationship so intriguing. We never truly know what draws these two together, yet the ambiguity allows food for thought.Stylistically, Lights is similar to Andrew Haigh's exceptional film "Weekend," which came out a few years ago. Though Haighs' film has a far more lighthearted plot than Lights, both films invite us to inhabit similar worlds of intimacy where sex and drugs are the common time-passer.Lights remains for me an abstract yet effective piece of work. The film jumps ahead 3-5 years in Paul and Erik's  relationship,  and we aren't clued in to every detail or event that happened between these years. We are left to fill in the blanks on are one. A sign that Sachs respects the intelligence of his audience.Pros: Great acting from leads, quite sexy, intelligently made, and great soundtrack featuring Authur Russell songsCons:  A bit repetitive due to nature of Erik and Paul's relationship.4/5
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is beyond doubt, for me anyway, one of the finest gay-themed films ever made. It will rip your heart out. It is the story of the decline of a lovely young man, victimized by crack cocaine addiction, and its horrendous effect on the loving, caring relationship with his partner. The screenplay, acting, direction, and attention to detail are remarkable. This film could easily serve as a cautionary tale when shown in LGTB centers and drug rehabs. This is a must-see!
summary: A Light Shining in the Wildnerness

reviewText: Rather flabby would-be examination of a troubled long-term relationship, characterized by one member's ongoing refusal to simply move on and stop being a human doormat to a crackhead.  Remarkably uninvolving on pretty much every level.

reviewText: I admit this movie was good on the merit of acting alone - it was completely believable. You found yourself believing you were a fly on the wall watching a real-life situation. But to me the movie felt like it was building up to making some point and it just didn't. I can't say that I can accurately describe what the point of this movie was.

reviewText: *** This review may contain spoilers ***While attending a recent screening of 'Keep the Lights On', director Ira Sachs indicated that the title of his new film about a gay romance spanning approximately ten years, refers to transparency, or lack thereof. An additional theme he revealed is that the characters are trapped in a masochistic relationship.The film begins as we're introduced to Erik, a documentary filmmaker from Denmark. He's basically supported by his father (much to the chagrin of his sister) who criticizes him for not having a regular job. Erik has just broken up with his lover and compulsively seeks out physical encounters with other gay men, using phone hot-lines (the film begins in 1998, at the time when phone hot-lines were beginning to be phased out, due to the rising popularity of the internet).Mr. Sachs holds little back in depicting the sexual encounters Erik has with strangers as well as his new found lover, Paul, a literary agent. They're not completely explicit but there's a raw immediacy, which gives the film an authentic verisimilitude--a peek at gay life that outsiders rarely are privy to.Sachs wisely chronicles the dichotomy of Erik's personality. On one hand, he's almost irrational in his obsession with Paul, ignoring the obvious reality that Paul is a drug addict and is rapidly going downhill. Erik also keeps a lot of things to himself and there is a lack of communication between the two lovers (that lack of transparency that Sachs alluded to during the recent screening I attended). On the plus side, Erik is deeply concerned about Paul's welfare and is instrumental in getting him into an inpatient program.While Paul has to struggle with his demons, Erik gradually makes good on his promise to become a successful documentary filmmaker. He wins a 'Teddy' Award in Berlin, after garnering acclaim for his documentary about a gay artist from the 40s and 50s, who Erik in effect, rescues from obscurity.The tension in the plot is bound up in guessing whether Paul is going to make it or not. After Paul returns from rehab, there's a great scene where he disappears for a number of days, and Erik and his friends have no idea where he is. When Erik finally finds him at a hotel, it's obvious that he's had a bad relapse. Erik hardly seems surprised when a young man comes over to have sex with Paul. Instead of getting angry and feeling betrayed, he accepts the fact that Paul has relapsed and holds his hand while Paul has casual sex with the stranger.'Keep the Lights On' slows down considerably in the third act, as Paul seemingly is much better after a few years and is now able to work. Erik's attitude has changed toward Paul, who has kept away from him for about a year. When Paul gives him an ultimatum--either break up or find a new home and live together--Erik, perhaps now realizing that their relationship has run its course, chooses the option of dissolution.Erik's obsessive love for Paul does eventually become tiresome and of course the point is that Erik must go through a process of self-actualization before he realizes he's been in a masochistic relationship. Nonetheless, Paul's breakdown and Erik's efforts to help him, is the best part of the picture. And yes we also want to know what the ultimate disposition is of their relationship.Director Sachs' portrait of Erik is of a gay man who is not isolated from the rest of society. He has female friends and well as straight male friends, and despite flights of sexual compulsivity, Erik comes off as someone who is pretty much part of the mainstream. In that respect, Mr. Sachs ably argues that gay people should not be considered 'outsiders', but ordinary people, who are no different than the average middle class straight person.A good part of 'Keep the Lights On' is strangely compelling. Will Paul overcome his addiction? Can Erik remain in the relationship, despite Paul's chequered history? Erik's 'love at any cost' obsession with Paul is necessary to show his self-destructiveness but by the same token, remains unexplained and goes on for a little too long. Some judicious editing, to make the film slightly shorter, would have helped. Nonetheless, this is a film that is definitely worth a look, not only for a few nice twists and turns in the plot, but the particularly strong performances from Thure Lindhardt and Zachary Booth, as the gay lovers, whose relationship reaches its nadir and then unceremoniously, fizzles out!
summary: Tale of Gay lover's efforts to save drug-addicted partner trumps his one-note obsession with him
